newsitem.title: INDIA: India Unitech eyes infrastructure boom.
newsitem.headline: India Unitech eyes infrastructure boom.

text.p: As India seeks to catch up with fast-growing East Asian "Tiger" economies, Unitech Ltd is seeing opportunities where others see bottlenecks -- real estate and infrastructure.
The company has lined up a series of foreign collaborations on its home turf, marking a change from the days when it saw its fortunes in exporting construction services to the Middle East.

"When the (Indian) economy opened up five years ago, real estate became more liberal," Unitech director G.R. Bahri told Reuters in an interview. "We thought a lot was going to happen in infrastructure, especially in roads and power."

Unitech, which has its roots in a modest consultancy started 25 years ago by Bahri and three other engineers, is now building towns, power transmission towers, a highway and a hotel with a total investment of 30 billion rupees ($857 million).
With real estate prices skyrocketing in cities like Bombay and Delhi, Unitech is building suburban townships, including office buildings, near Delhi, Bombay, Bangalore and Lucknow.
"We expect that corporate relocation will take place," Bahri said, pointing to a recent decision by multinational PepsiCo to buy an office building outside Delhi.

Unitech this month starts work on Signature Towers, a 325,000 square-foot (29,545 square metre) commercial complex in the middle of Unitech's 325-acre (130-hectare) South City township near Delhi in the state of Haryana.

The "world class" building designed in Singapore and costing 2.0 billion rupees would be built by a consortium that includes Unitech, expatriate Indians and Singapore's First Capital Corp, Bahri said.
Unitech has another venture with First Capital and Technology Parks Ltd to build an industrial complex in Haryana.
Another joint venture, in which Unitech holds 75 percent, is building a five-star hotel close to Delhi airport affiliated to the Radisson group.
Unitech's main projects are in Haryana which is becoming a haven for developers and customers looking for a way out of Delhi's high real estate prices.
Across the state that surrounds Delhi on three sides, Unitech is building a 2.42 billion rupee four-lane highway in collaboration with South Korea's LG (Lucky Goldstar) group.

Seeing opportunity in India's chronic power shortage, Unitech is also building a facility to make power transmission towers with South Korea's Hyundai Engineering and Construction Company. It eventually plans to erect the towers as well as build them.
Unitech also has a plant to make ready-to-use concrete in a venture with Singapore's Resources Development Corp.
Total income was expected to grow by about 40 percent in 1996/97 (April-March) from 2.6 billion rupees ($74 million) in 1995/96, Bahri said.
The four engineers who founded Unitech, along with their associates, hold more than 50 percent of the company's 125 million rupee ($3.5 million) share capital, Bahri said.

As much as 24 percent is held by foreign institutional investors and expatriate Indians. Under Indian regulatory laws, foreign portfolio investors cannot hold more than 24 percent of an Indian company.
